sp.p: That 's what was slipped me . Seems that one of the richest men that is in on Mr. Burgess 's address-book is a fellow named Brockton from downtown some place . He 's got more money than the Shoe and Leather National Bank . He likes to play show business .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Rises quickly .Crosses to wardrobe , gets hat ; crosses to dresser , gets scissors with intention of curling feathers .Oh !

sp.speaker: JIM
sp.p: I thought you knew him . I thought it was just as well to tell you where he and Burgess stand . They 're pals .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Coming over to JIM and with emphasis crosses to down-stage side of bed ; puts hat and scissors on bed .I do n't want you to talk about him or any of them . I just want you to know that I 'm trying to do everything in my power to go through this season without any more trouble . I 've pawned everything I 've got ; I 've cut every friend I knew . But where am I going to end ? That 's what I want to know — where am I going to end ?To bed and sits .Every place I look for a position something interferes . It 's almost as if I were blacklisted . I know I could get jobs all right if I wanted to pay the price , but I wo n't . I just want to tell you , I wo n't . No !

div.stage: Rises , crosses to mantel , rests elbow .

sp.speaker: JIM
sp.p: That 's the way to talk .Rises .I do n't know you very well , but I 've watched you close . I 'm just a common , ordinary showman who never had much money , and I 'm going out o ’ date . I 've spent most of my time with nigger-minstrel shows and circuses , but I 've been on the square . That 's why I 'm broke .Rather sadly .Once I thought the missis would have to go back and do her acrobatic act , but she could n't do that , she 's grown so damn fat .Crosses to LAURA .Just you do n't mind . It 'll all come out right .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: It 's an awful tough game , is n't it ?

sp.speaker: JIM
sp.p: During this speech LAURA gets cup , pours milk back into bottle , closes biscuit-box , puts milk on shed outside , and biscuits into wardrobe , cup in alcove .It 's hell forty ways from the Jack . It 's tough for me , but for a pretty woman with a lot o ’ rich fools jumping out o ’ their automobiles and hanging around stage doors , it must be something awful . I ai n't blaming the women . They say “ self-preservation is the first law of nature , ” and I guess that 's right ; but sometimes when the show is over and I see them fellows with their hair plastered back , smoking cigarettes in aLAURA crosses to chair right of table and leans over back .holder long enough to reach from here to Harlem , and a bank-roll that would bust my pocket and turn my head , I feel as if I 'd like to get a gun and go a-shooting around this old town .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Jim !

sp.speaker: JIM
sp.p: Yes , I do — you bet .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: That would n't pay , would it ?

sp.speaker: JIM
sp.p: No , they 're not worth the job of sitting on that throne in Sing Sing , and I 'm too poor to go to Matteawan . But all them fellows under nineteen and over fifty-nine ai n't much use to themselves or anyone else .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Rather meditatively .Perhaps all of them are not so bad .

sp.speaker: JIM
sp.p: Sits on bed .Yes , they are ,— angels and all . Last season I had one of them shows where a rich fellow backed it on account of a girl . We lost money and he lost his girl ; then we got stuck in Texas . I telegraphed : “ Must have a thousand , or can n't move . ” He just answered : “ Do n't move . ” We did n't .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: But that was business .

sp.speaker: JIM
sp.p: Bad business . It took a year for some of them folks to get back to Broadway . Some of the girls never did , and I guess never will .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Sits right of table .Maybe they 're better off , Jim .

sp.speaker: JIM
sp.p: Could n't be worse . They 're still in Texas .To himself .Wish I knew how to do something else , being a plumber or a walking delegate ; they always have jobs .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Well , I wish I could do something else too , but I can n't , and we 've got to make the best of it .

sp.speaker: JIM
sp.p: I guess so . I 'll see you this evening . I hope you 'll have good news by that time .Starts to exit , about to open door ; then retreats a step , with hand on door-knob , crosses and in a voice meant to be kindlyIf you 'd like to go to the theatre to-night , and take some other woman in the house , maybe I can get a couple of tickets for some of the shows . I know a lot of fellows who are working .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: No , thanks . I have n't anything to wear to the theatre , and I do n't —

sp.speaker: JIM
sp.p: With a smile crosses to LAURA , puts arm around her .Now you just cheer up ! Something 's sure to turn up . It always has for me , and I 'm a lot older than you , both in years and in this business . There 's always a break in hard luck sometime — that 's sure .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Smiling through her tears .I hope so . But things are looking pretty hopeless now , are n't they ?

sp.speaker: JIM
sp.p: I 'll go down and give Mrs. F. a line o ’ talk and try to square you for a couple of days more anyway . But I guess she 's laying pretty close to the cushion herself , poor woman .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Annie says a lot of people owe her .

sp.speaker: JIM
sp.p: Well , you can n't pay what you have n't got . And even if money was growing on trees , it 's winter now .JIM goes towards door .I 'm off . Maybe to-day is lucky day . So long !

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Good-bye .

sp.speaker: JIM
sp.p: ExitKeep your nerve .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: I will .She sits for a moment in deep thought , picks up the letter received , as if to read it , and then throws it down in anger . She buries her head in hands .I can n't stand it — I just simply can n't stand it .

sp.speaker: MRS. FARLEY 'S VOICE
sp.p: Off stage .Miss Murdock — Miss Murdock .

lg.stage: Brushing away tears , rises , goes to door , and opens it .
lg.l: What is it ?

sp.speaker: SAME VOICE
sp.p: There 's a lady down here to see you .

sp.speaker: ELFIE 'S VOICE
sp.p: Off stage .Hello , dearie , can I come up ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Is that you , Elfie ?

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: Yes ; shall I come up ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Why , certainly . She waits at the door for a moment , and ELFIE ST. CLAIR appears . She is gorgeously gowned in the rather extreme style affected by the usual New York woman who is cared for by a gentleman of wealth and who has not gone through the formality of matrimonial alliance . Her conduct is always exaggerated and her attitude vigorous . Her gown is of the latest design , and in every detail of dress she shows evidence of most extravagant expenditure . She carries a hand-bag of gold , upon which are attached such trifles as a gold cigarette-case , a gold powder-box , pencils , and the like . ELFIE throws her arms around LAURA , and both exchange kisses .

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: Laura , you old dearCrossing to table ., I 've just found out where you 've been hiding , and came around to see you .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Who is much brightened by ELFIE 'S appearance .Elfie , you 're looking bully . How are you , dear ?

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: Fine .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Come in and sit down . I have n't much to offer , but —

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: Oh , never mind . It 's such a grand day outside , and I 've come around in my car to take you out .Sits right of table .You know I 've got a new one , and it can go some .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Sits on arm of chair .I am sorry , but I can n't go out this afternoon , Elfie .

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: What 's the matter ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: You see I 'm staying home a good deal nowadays . I have n't been feeling very well and I do n't go out much .

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: I should think not . I have n't seen you in Rector 's or Martin 's since you come back from Denver . Got a glimpse of you one day trailing up Broadway , but could n't get to you — you dived into some office or other .For the first time she surveys the room , rises , looks around critically , crossing to mantel .Gee ! Whatever made you come into a dump like this ? It 's the limit .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Crossing and standing back of the table .Oh , I know it is n't pleasant , but it 's my home , and after all — a home 's a home .

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: Looks more like a prison .Takes candy from mantel ; spits it out on floor .Makes me think of the old days of Child 's sinkers and a hall bedroom .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Leaning hands on table .It 's comfortable .

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: Sits on bed , trying bed with comedy effect . Say , is this here for an effect , or do you sleep on it ?Not !

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: I sleep on it .

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: No wonder you look tired . Say , listen , dearie . What else is the matter with you anyway ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Nothing .

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: Yes , there is . What happened between you and Brockton ?Notices faded flowers in vase on table ; takes them out , tosses them into fireplace , replaces them with gardenias which she wears .He 's not broke , because I saw him the other day .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Where ?

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: In the park . Asked me out to luncheon , but I could n't go . You know , dearie , I 've got to be so careful . Jerry 's so awful jealous — the old fool .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Do you see much of Jerry nowadays , Elfie ?

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: Not any more than I can help and be nice . He gets on my nerves . Of course , I 've heard about your quitting Brockton .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Then why do you ask ?

div.stage: Crosses around chair right of table ; stands .

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: Just wanted to hear from your own dear lips what the trouble was . Now tell me all about it . Can I smoke here ?

div.stage: Takes cigarette-case up , opens it , selecting cigarette .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Gets matches off bureau , puts them on table .Surely .

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: Offers case .Have one ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: No , thank you .

div.stage: Sits in chair right of table , facing ELFIE .

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: H'mhYpppHeNm , h'mhYpppHeNm , hah !Lights cigarette .Now go ahead . Tell me all the scandal . I 'm just crazy to know .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: There 's nothing to tell . I have n't been able to find work , that is all , and I 'm short of money . You can n't live in hotels , you know , with cabs and all that sort of thing , when you 're not working .

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: Yes , you can . I have n't worked in a year .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: But you do n't understand , dear . I — I — Well , you know I — well , you know — I can n't say what I want .

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: Oh , yes , you can . You can say anything to me — everybody else does . We 've been pals . I know you got along a little faster in the business than I did . The chorus was my limit , and you went into the legitimate thing . But we got our living just the same way . I did n't suppose there was any secret between you and me about that .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: I know there was n't then , Elfie , but I tell you I 'm different now . I do n't want to do that sort of thing , and I 've been very unlucky . This has been a terribly hard season for me . I simply have n't been able to get an engagement .

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: Well , you can n't get on this way . Wo n'tPauses , knocking ashes off cigarette to cover hesitation .Brockton help you out ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: What 's the use of talking to youRises and crosses to fireplace ., Elfie ; you do n't understand .

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: Puffing deliberately on cigarette and crossing her legs in almost a masculine attitude .No ? Why do n't I understand ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Because you can n't ; you 've never felt as I have .

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: How do you know ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Turning impatiently .Oh , what 's the use of explaining ?

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: You know , Laura , I 'm not much on giving advice , but you make me sick . I thought you 'd grown wise . A young girl just butting into this business might possibly make a fool of herself , but you ought to be on to the game and make the best of it .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Going over to her angrily .Sits on bed .If you came up here , Elfie , to talk that sort of stuff to me , please do n't . I was West this summer . I met someone , a real man , who did me a whole lot of good ,— a man who opened my eyes to a different way of going along — a man who — Oh , well , what 's the use ? You do n't know — you do n't know .

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: Throws cigarette into fireplace .I do n't know , do n't I ? I do n't know , I suppose , that when I came to this town from up state ,— a little burg named Oswego ,— and joined a chorus , that I did n't fall in love with just such a man . I suppose I do n't know that then I was the best-looking girl in New York , and everybody talked about me ? I suppose I do n't know that there were men , all ages and with all kinds of money , ready to give me anything for the mere privilege of taking me out to supper ? And I did n't do it , did I ? For three years I stuck by this good man who was to lead me in a good way toward a good life . And all the time I was getting older , never quite so pretty one day as I had been the day before . I never knew then what it was to be tinkered with by hair-dressers and manicures or a hundred and one of those other people who make you look good . I did n't have to have them then .Rises , crosses to right of table , facing LAURA .Well , you know , Laura , what happened .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Was n't it partly your fault , Elfie ?

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: Speaking across table angrily .Was it my fault that time made me older and I took on a lot of flesh ? Was it my fault that the work and the life took out the colour , and left the make-up ? Was it my fault that other pretty young girls came along , just as I 'd come , and were chased after , just as I was ? Was it my fault the cabs were n't waiting any more and people did n't talk about how pretty I was ? And was it my fault when he finally had me alone , and just because no one else wanted me , he got tired and threw me flat — cold flatBrings hand down on table .— and I 'd been on the dead level with him !With almost a sob , crosses up to bureau , powders nose , comes down back of table .It almost broke my heart . Then I made up my mind to get even and get all I could out of the game . Jerry came along . He was a has-been and I was on the road to be . He wanted to be good to me , and I let him . That 's all .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Still , I do n't see how you can live that way .

div.stage: Lies on bed .

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: Well , you did , and you did n't kick .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Yes , but things are different with me now . You 'd be the same way if you were in my place .

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: No . I 've had all the romance I want , and I 'll stake you to all your love affairs .Crosses back of bed , touches picture over bed .I am out to gather in as much coin as I can in my own way , so when the old rainy day comes along I 'll have a little change to buy myself an umbrella .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Rising and angrily crossing to armchair .What did you come here for ? Why can n't you leave me alone when I 'm trying to get along ?

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: Because I want to help you .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: During speech crosses to up-stage side of bed , angrily tosses quilt to floor and sits on bed in tears .You can n't help me . I 'm all right — I tell you I am . What do you care anyway ?

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: Sits on bed , crosses down stage to lower left side of bed , sits facing LAURA .But I do care . I know how you feel with an old cat for a landlady and living up here on a side street with a lot of cheap burlesque people . Why , the room 's coldLAURA rises , crosses to window ., and there 's no hot water , and you 're beginning to look shabby . You have n't got a job — chances are you wo n't have one . What doesIndicating picture on bed with thumb .this fellow out there do for you ? Send you long letters of condolences ? That 's what I used to get . When I wanted to buy a new pair of shoes or a silk petticoat , he told me how much he loved me ; so I had the other ones re-soled and turned the old petticoat . And look at you , you 're beginning to show it .She surveys her carefully .I do believe there are lines coming in your faceLAURA crosses to dresser quickly , picks up hand mirror , and looks at herself ., and you hide in the house because you 've nothing new to wear .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Puts down mirror , crossing down to back of bed .But I 've got what you have n't got . I may have to hide my clothes , but I do n't have to hide my face . And you with that man — he 's old enough to be your father — a toddling dote hanging on your apron-strings . I do n't see how you dare show your face to a decent woman .

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: Rises .Crossing to fireplace .You do n't !— but you did once and I never caught you hanging your head . You say he 's old . I know he 's old , but he 's good to me . He 's making what 's left of my life pleasant . You think I like him . I do n't ,— sometimes I hate him ,— but he understands ; and you can bet your life his check is in my mail every Saturday night or there 's a new lock on the door Sunday morning .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: How can you say such things to me ?

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: Crosses to left end of table .Because I want you to be square with yourself . You 've lost all that precious virtue women gab about . When you 've got the name , I say get the game .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: You can go now , Elfie , and do n't come back .

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: Gathering up muff , & c .A knock on the door .All right , if that 's the way you want it to be , I 'm sorry .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Controlling herself after a moment 's hesitation .Come in . ANNIE enters with a note , crosses , and hands it to LAURA .

sp.speaker: ANNIE
sp.p: Mis ’ Farley sent dis , Miss Laura .

div.stage: LAURA takes the note and reads it . She is palpably annoyed .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: There 's no answer .

sp.speaker: ANNIE
sp.p: She tol ’ me not to leave until Ah got an answah .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: You must ask her to wait .

sp.speaker: ANNIE
sp.p: She wants an answah .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Tell her I 'll be right down — that it will be all right .

sp.speaker: ANNIE
sp.p: But , Miss Laura , she tol ’ me to get an answah .

div.stage: Exit reluctantly .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Half to herself and half to ELFIE .Standing near door .She 's taking advantage of your being here .

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: How ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: She wants money — three weeks ’ room-rent . I presume she thought you 'd give it to me .

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: Moves to left .Huh !

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Crossing to table .Elfie , I 've been a little cross ; I did n't mean it .

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: Well ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Could — could you lend me thirty-five dollars until I get to work ?

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: Me ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: Lend you thirty-five dollars ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Yes ; you 've got plenty of money to spare .

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: Well , you certainly have got a nerve .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: You might give it to me . I have n't a dollar in the world , and you pretend to be such a friend to me !

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: Turning and angrily speaking across table .So that 's the kind of woman you are , eh ? A moment ago you were going to kick me out of the place because I was n't decent enough to associate with you . You know how I live . You know how I get my money — the same way you got most of yours . And now that you 've got this spasm of goodness I 'm not fit to be in your room ; but you 'll take my money to pay your debts . You 'll let me go out and do this sort of thing for your benefit , while you try to play the grand lady . I 've got your number now , Laura . Where in hell is your virtue anyway ? You can go to the devil — rich , poor , or any other way . I 'm off ! ELFIE rushes toward door ; for a moment LAURA stands speechless , then bursts into hysterics .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Elfie ! Elfie ! Do n't go now ! Do n't leave me now !ELFIE hesitates with hand on door-knob .I can n't stand it . I can n't be alone . Do n't go , please ; do n't go . LAURA falls into ELFIE 'S arms , sobbing . In a moment ELFIE 'S whole demeanour changes and she melts into the tenderest womanly sympathy , trying her best to express herself in her crude way .

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: There , old girl , do n't cry , do n't cry . You just sit down here and let me put my arms around you .ELFIE leads LAURA over to armchair , places muff , & c ., in chair , and sits LAURA down in chair . ELFIE sits on right arm of chair with her left arm behind LAURA ; hugs LAURA to her . LAURA in tears and sobbing during scene .I 'm awful sorry — on the level , I am . I should n't have said it . I know that . But I 've got feelings too , even if folks do n't give me credit for it .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: I know , Elfie . I 've gone through about all I can stand .

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: Well , I should say you have — and more than I would . Anyway a good cry never hurts any woman . I have one myself , sometimes — under cover .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: More seriously , recovering herself .Perhaps what you said was true .

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: We wo n't talk about it .

div.stage: Wiping LAURA 'S eyes and kissing her .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: With persistence .But perhaps it was true , and , Elfie —

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: I think I 've stood this just as long as I can . Every day is a living horror .

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: Looking around room .It 's the limit .

lg.l: I 've got to have money to pay the rent . I 've pawned everything
I have , except the clothes on my back .

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: I 'll give you all the money you need , dearie . Great heavens , do n't worry about that . Do n't you care if I got sore and — and lost my head .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: No ; I can n't let you do that .Rises ; crosses to table .Sits right of table .You may have been mad ,— awfully mad ,— but what you said was the truth . I can n't take your money .

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: Rises , crosses to centre .Oh , forget that .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Maybe — maybe if he knew all about it — the suffering — he would n't blame me .

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: Who — the good man who wanted to lead you to the good life without even a bread-basket for an advance-agent ? Huh !

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Still he does n't know how desperately poor I am .

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: He knows you 're out of work , do n't he ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Turning to ELFIE .Not exactly . I 've let him think that I 'm getting along all right .

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: Then you 're a chump . Has n't he sent you anything ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: He has n't anything to send .

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: Well , what does he think you 're going to live on ?— asphalt croquettes with conversation sauce ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Sobbing .I do n't know — I do n't know .

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: Crosses to LAURA , puts arms around her .Do n't be foolish , dearie . You know there is somebody waiting for you — somebody who 'll be good to you and get you out of this mess .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Looking up .You mean Will Brockton ?

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Do you know where he is ?

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Well ?

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: You wo n't get sore again if I tell you , will you ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Rises .No — why ?

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: He 's downstairs — waiting in the car . I promised to tell him what you said .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Then it was all planned , and — and —

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: Now , dearie , I knew you were up against it , and I wanted to bring you two together . He 's got half of the Burgess shows , and if you 'll only see him everything will be fixed .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: When does he want to see me ?

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: Now .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Here ?

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: Yes . Shall I tell him to come up ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: After a long pause , crossing around to bed , down-stage side .Yes .

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: Suddenly becomes animated .Now you 're a sensible dear . I 'll bet he 's half frozen down there .Goes to door .I 'll send him up . Look at you , Laura , you 're a sight .Crosses to LAURA , takes her by hand , leads her up to washstand , takes towel and wipes LAURA 'S eyes .It 'll never do to have him see you looking like this ; come over here and let me fix your eyes . Now , Laura , I want you to promise me you wo n't do any more crying .Leads LAURA over to dresser , takes powder-puff and powders LAURA 'S face .Come over here and let me powder your nose . Now when he comes up you tell him he has got to blow us all off to a dinner to-night at Martin 's , seven-thirty . Let me look at you . Now you 're all right .After daubing LAURA 'S face with the rouge paw , ELFIE takes LAURA 'S face in her hands and kisses her .Make it strong now , seven-thirty , do n't forget . I 'll be there .Crosses to armchair , gathers up muff , & c .So long .Exit .After ELFIE 'S exit LAURA crosses slowly to wardrobe , pulls off picture of JOHN ; crosses to dresser , takes picture of JOHN from there ; carries both pictures over to bed ; kneels on bed , pulls down picture at head of bed ; places all three pictures under pillow . WILL is heard coming upstairs , and knocks .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Come in .

div.stage: WILL enters . His dress is that of a man of business , the time being about February . He is well groomed and brings with him the impression of easy luxury .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: As he enters .Hello , Laura . There is an obvious embarrassment on the part of each of them . She rises , goes to him and extends her hand .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: I 'm — I 'm glad to see you , Will .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Thank you .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Wo n't you sit down ?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Regaining his ease of manner .Thank you again .

div.stage: Puts hat and cane at end of wardrobe ; removes overcoat and places it on back of armchair ; sits in armchair .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Sits right of table .It 's rather cold out , is n't it ?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Just a bit sharp .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: You came with Elfie in the car ?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: She picked me up at Martin 's ; we lunched there .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: By appointment ?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: I 'd asked her .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Well ?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Well , Laura .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: She told you ?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Not a great deal . What do you want to tell me ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Very simply , and avoiding his glance .Will , I 'm ready to come back .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: With an effort concealing his sense of triumph and satisfaction . Rises , crosses to LAURA .I 'm mighty glad of that , Laura . I 've missed you like the very devil .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Do we — do we have to talk it over much ?

div.stage: Crosses to left of table in front of bed .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Not at all unless you want to . I understand — in fact , I always have .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Wearily .Yes , I guess you always did . I did n't .

div.stage: Crosses and sits right of table .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: It will be just the same as it was before , you know .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: I did n't think it was possible for me to miss anyone the way I have you . I 've been lonely .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: That 's nice in you to say that .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: You 'll have to move out of here right away .Crossing to back of table , surveying room .This place is enough to give one the colly-wabbles . If you 'll be ready to-morrow I 'll send my man over to help you take care of the luggage .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: To-morrow will be all right , thank you .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: And you 'll need some money in the meantime . I 'll leave this here .

div.stage: He takes a roll of bills and places it on the bureau .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: You seem to have come prepared . Did Elfie and you plan this all out ?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Not planned — just hoped . I think you 'd better go to some nice hotel now . Later we can arrange .

div.stage: Sits on up-stage side of bed .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Will , we 'll always be frank . I said I was ready to go . It 's up to you — when and where .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: The hotel scheme is the best , but , Laura —

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Yes ?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: You 're quite sure this is in earnest . You do n't want to change ? You 've time enough now .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: I 've quite made up my mind . It 's final .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: If you want to work , Burgess has a nice part for you . I 'll telephone and arrange if you say so .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Thanks . Say I 'll see him in the morning .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: And , Laura , you know when we were in Denver , and —

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Rises hurriedly ; crosses right .Please , please , do n't speak of it .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: I 'm sorry , but I 've got to . I toldRises , and crosses to left .MadisonLAURA turns her head .— pardon me , but I must do this — that if this time ever came I 'd have you write him the truth . Before we go any further I 'd like you to do that now .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Turns to WILL .Say good-bye ?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Just that .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: I would n't know how to begin . It will hurt him awfully deeply .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: It 'll be worse if you do n't . He 'll like you for telling him . It would be honest , and that is what he expects .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Must I — now ?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: I think you should .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Goes to table and sits down .How shall I begin , Will ?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Standing back of table .You mean you do n't know what to say ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Then I 'll dictate .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: I 'll do just as you say . You 're the one to tell me now .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Address it the way you want to .She complies .I 'm going to be pretty brutal . In the long run I think that is best , do n't you ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: It 's up to you .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Ready ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Begin .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Dictating .“ All I have to say can be expressed in one word , ‘ good-bye . ’ I shall not tell you where I 've gone , but remind you of what Brockton told you the last time he saw you . He is here nowPause ., dictating this letter . What I am doing is voluntary — my own suggestion . Do n't grieve . Be happy and successful . I do not love you ” —

div.stage: She puts pen down ; looks at him .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Will — please .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: It has got to go just that way — “ I do not love you . ” Sign it “ Laura . ”She does it .Fold it , put it in an envelope — seal it — address it . Now shall I mail it ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: No . If you do n't mind I 'd sooner . It 's a sort of a last — last message .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Crosses to armchair ; gets coat , puts it on .Gets hat and cane .All right . You 're a little upset now , and I 'm going . We are all to dine at Martin 's to-night at seven-thirty . There 'll be a party . Of course you 'll come .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: I do n't think I can . You see —

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: I know . I guess there 's enough thereIndicating money .for your immediate needs . Later you can straighten things up . Shall I send the car ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Yes , please .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Good . It will be the first happy evening I 've had in a long , long time . You 'll be ready ?

div.stage: Approaches and bends over her as if to caress her .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Shrinking away .Please do n't . Remember we do n't dine until seven-thirty .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Exit .All right . For a moment LAURA sits silent , and then angrily rises , crosses up to dresser , gets alcohol lamp , crosses to table with lamp , lights same , and starts back to dresser . Knock at door .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Come in .ANNIE enters , and stops .That you , Annie ?

sp.speaker: ANNIE
sp.p: Yassum .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Mrs. Farley wants her rent . There is some money .Tosses money on to table .Take it to her . ANNIE goes to the table , examines the roll of bills and is palpably surprised .

sp.speaker: ANNIE
sp.p: Dey ai n't nothin ’ heah , Miss Laura , but five great big one hunderd dollah bills .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: ANNIE complies .Take two . And look in that upper drawer . You 'll find some pawn tickets there .

sp.speaker: ANNIE
sp.p: Yassum .Aside .Dat 's real money — dem 's yellow-backs sure .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Take the two top ones and go get my lace gown and one of the hats . The ticket is for a hundred and ten dollars . Keep ten for yourself , and hurry .

sp.speaker: ANNIE
sp.p: Aside .Ten for myself — I never see so much money .To LAURA , her astonishment nearly overcoming her .Yassum , Miss Laura , yassum .She goes toward door , and then turns to LAURA .Ah 'm so mighty glad yo ’ out all yo ’ trouble , Miss Laura . I says to Mis ’ Farley now —

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Snapping her off .Do n't — do n't . Go do as I tell you and mind your business .ANNIE turns sullenly and walks toward the door . At that moment LAURA sees the letter , which she has thrown on the table .Wait a minute . I want you to mail a letter .By this time her hair is half down , hanging loosely over her shoulders . Her waist is open at the throat , collar off , and she has the appearance of a woman 's untidiness when she is at that particular stage of her toilet . Hands letter to ANNIE , but snatches it away as ANNIE turns to go . She glances at the letter long and wistfully , and her nerve fails her .Never mind .

div.stage: ANNIE exits . Slowly LAURA puts the letter over the flame of the alcohol lamp and it ignites . As it burns she holds it in her fingers , and when half consumed throws it into waste-jar , sits on side of bed watching letter burn , then lies down across bed on her elbows , her chin in her hands , facing audience . As the last flicker is seen the curtain slowly descends .
CURTAIN .

div.head: SCENE . Two months have elapsed . The scene is at BROCKTON 'S

stage.stage: apartment in a hotel such as is not over particular concerning the relations of its tenants . There are a number of these hotels throughout the theatre district of New York , and , as a rule , one will find them usually of the same type . The room in which this scene is placed is that of the general living-room in one of the handsomest apartments in the building . The prevailing colour is green , and there is nothing particularly gaudy about the general furnishings . They are in good taste , but without the variety of arrangement and ornamentation which would naturally obtain in a room occupied by people a bit more particular concerning their surroundings . Down stage is a table about three feet square which can be used not only as a general centre-table , but also for service while the occupants are eating . There is a breakfast service on this table , and also a tray and stand behind it . There is a chair at either side of the table , and at right coming up stage , the room turns at a sharp angle of thirty-five degrees , and this space is largely taken up by a large doorway . This is equipped with sliding-doors and hung with green portières , which are handsome and in harmony with the general scheme of the furnishings of the room . This entrance is to the sleeping-room of the apartments .

At the back of the stage is a large window or alcove . The window is on the ordinary plan , and the view through it shows the back of another building of New York , presumably a hotel of about the same character . Green portières are also hung on the windows . Down left is the entrance to the corridor of the hotel , and this must be so arranged that it works with a latch-key and opens upon a small hallway , which separates the apartment from the main hallway . This is necessary as the action calls for the slamming of a door , and later the opening of the direct and intimate door of the apartment with a latch-key . Left of centre is a sofa , and there is a general arrangement of chairs without over-crowding the apartment . Just below , where the right portière is hung , is a long , full-length mirror , such as women dress by . Against wall is a lady 's fancy dresser .

To the immediate left of the sliding-doors , which go into the sleeping-apartment , is a lady 's small writing-desk , with a drawer on the right-hand side , in which is a pearl-handled 32-calibre revolver . The front of the desk is open at rise . On top of the desk is a desk lamp and a large box of candy ; inside the desk is writing material , & c. In pigeon-hole left there is a small photo and frame , which ANNIE places on the table when she removes the breakfast set . In front of centre window in alcove is a small table on which is a parlour lamp , and some newspapers , including the “ New York Sun . ” On the floor running between the desk and table is a large fur rug . In front of the table is a small gilt chair ; in front of desk there is also a small gilt chair ; there is a pianola piano , on top of which is a bundle of music-rolls . In place , ready to play , is a roll of a negro tune called “ Bon-Bon Buddie , My Chocolate Drop . ” On top of the piano , in addition to the music-rolls , are a fancy lamp , a large basket of chrysanthemums , and two photos in frames , at the upper corner . Standing on the floor is a large piano lamp . On the sofa are cushions , and thrown over its back is a lady 's opera-coat . On the sofa are also a fan and some small dinner favours .

On the dresser are a lady 's silver toilet set , including powder boxes , rouge boxes , manicuring implements , and a small plush black cat that might have been a favour at some time . Two little dolls hang on the side of the glass of the dresser , which also might have been favours . These are used later in the action , and are necessary .

sp.speaker: AT RISE
sp.p: When the curtain rises on this scene it is noticeable that the occupants of the room must have returned rather late at night , after having dined , not wisely , but too well . In the alcove is a man 's dress-coat and vest thrown on the cushions in a most careless manner ; a silk hat badly rumpled is near it . Over the top of sofa is an opera-cloak , and hung on the mirror is a huge hat , of the evening type , such as women would pay handsomely for . A pair of gloves is thrown on top of the pier-glass . The curtains in the bay-window are half drawn , and the light shades are half drawn down the windows , so that when the curtain goes up the place is in a rather dim light . On the table are the remains of a breakfast , which is served in a box-like tray such as is used in hotels . LAURA is discovered sitting at right of table , her hair a bit untidy . She has on a very expensive negligée gown . WILL , in a business suit , is at the other side of the table , and both have evidently just about concluded their breakfast and are reading the newspapers while they sip their coffee . LAURA is intent in the scanning of her “ Morning Telegraph , ” while WILL is deep in the market reports of the “ Journal of Commerce , ” and in each instance these things must be made apparent . WILL throws down the paper rather impatiently .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Have you seen the Sun , Laura ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Where is it ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: I do n't know .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: In a loud voice .Annie , Annie !A pause .Annie !In an undertone , half directed to LAURA .Where the devil is that nigger ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Why , I suppose she 's at breakfast .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Well , she ought to be here .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Did it ever occur to you that she has got to eat just the same as you have ?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: She 's your servant , is n't she ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: My maid .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Well , what have you got her for ,— to eat or to wait on you ? Annie !

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Do n't be so cross . What do you want ?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: I want the Sun .

div.stage: BROCKTON pours out one half glass of water from bottle .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: I will get it for you . Rather wearily she gets up and goes to the table , where there are other morning papers ; she takes the “ Sun , ” hands it to him , goes back to her seat , re-opens the “ Morning Telegraph . ” There is a pause . ANNIE enters from the sleeping-room .

sp.speaker: ANNIE
sp.p: Do yuh want me , suh ?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Yes , I did want you , but do n't now . When I 'm at home I have a man to look after me , and I get what I want .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: For heaven 's sake , Will , have a little patience . If you like your man so well , you had better live at home , but do n't come around here with a grouch and bulldoze everybody .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Do n't think for a moment that there 's much to come around here for . Annie , this room 's stuffy .

sp.speaker: ANNIE
sp.p: Yassuh .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Draw those portières . Let those curtains up .ANNIE lets up curtain .Let 's have a little light . Take away these clothes and hide them . Do n't you know that a man does n't want to see the next morning anything to remind him of the night before . Make the place look a little respectable . In the meantime ANNIE scurries around , picking up the coat and vest , opera-cloak , & c ., as rapidly as possible , and throwing them over her arm without any idea of order . It is very apparent that she is rather fearful of the anger of WILL while he is in this mood .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Looking at her .Be careful . You 're not taking the wash off the line .

sp.speaker: ANNIE
sp.p: Exit in confusion .Yassuh .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Laying down paper and looking at WILL .Well , I must say you 're rather amiable this morning .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: I feel like hell .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Market unsatisfactory ?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: No ; head too big .He lights a cigar ; as he takes a puff he makes an awful face .Puts cigar into cup .Tastes like punk .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: You drank a lot .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: We 'll have to cut out those parties . I can n't do those things any more . I 'm not as young as I was , and in the morning it makes me sick . How do you feel ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Rises , and crosses to bureau .A little tired , that 's all .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: You did n't touch anything ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: I guess you 're on the safe side . It was a great old party , though , was n't it ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Did you think so ?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Oh , for that sort of a blow-out . Not too rough , but just a little easy . I like them at night and I hate them in the morning .He picks up the paper and commences to glance it over in a casual manner , not interrupting his conversation .Were you bored ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Yes ; always at things like that .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Well , you do n't have to go .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: You asked me .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: LAURA picks up paper , puts it on table and crosses back to bureau .Still , you could say no .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: But you asked me .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: What did you go for if you did n't want to ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: You wanted me to .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: I do n't quite get you .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Well , Will , you have all my time when I 'm not in the theatre , and you can do with it just what you please . You pay for it . I 'm working for you .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Is that all I 've got ,— just your time ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Wearily .That and the rest .LAURA crosses up to desk , gets “ part , ” crosses to sofa , turning pages of “ part . ”Crosses to sofa and sits .I guess you know .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Looking at her curiously .Down in the mouth , eh ? I 'm sorry .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: No , only if you want me to be frank , I 'm a little tired . You may not believe it , but I work awfully hard over at the theatre . Burgess will tell you that . I know I 'm not so very good as an actress , but I try to be .LAURA lies down on sofa .I 'd like to succeed , myself . They 're very patient with me . Of course they 've got to be ,— that 's another thing you 're paying for , but I do n't seem to get along except this way .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Oh , do n't get sentimental . If you 're going to bring up that sort of talk , Laura , do it sometime when I have n't got a hang-over , and then do n't forget talk never does count for much . LAURA crosses up to mirror , picks up hat from box , puts it on , looks in mirror . She turns around and looks at him steadfastly for a minute . During this entire scene , from the time the curtain rises , she must in a way indicate a premonition of an approaching catastrophe , a feeling , vague but nevertheless palpable , that something is going to happen . She must hold this before her audience so that she can show to them , without showing to him , the disgust she feels . LAURA has tasted of the privations of self-sacrifice during her struggle , and she has weakly surrendered and is unable to go back , but that brief period of self-abnegation has shown to her most clearly the rottenness of the other sort of living . There are enough sentimentality and emotion in her character to make it impossible for her to accept this manner of existence as ELFIE does . Hers is not a nature of careless candour , but of dreamy ideals and better living , warped , handicapped , disillusioned , and destroyed by a weakness that finds its principal force in vanity . WILL resumes his newspaper in a more attentive way . The girl looks at him and expresses in pantomime , by the slightest gesture or shrug of the shoulders , her growing distaste for him and his way of living . In the meantime WILL is reading the paper rather carefully . He stops suddenly and then looks at his watch .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: What time is it ?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: After ten .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Oh . WILL at this moment particularly reads some part of the paper , turns to her with a keen glance of suspicion and inquiry , and then for a very short moment evidently settles in his mind a cross-examination . He has read in this paper a despatch from Chicago , which speaks of JOHN MADISON having arrived there as a representative of a big Western mining syndicate which is going to open large operations in the Nevada gold-fields , and representing MR. MADISON as being on his way to New York with sufficient capital to enlist more , and showing him to be now a man of means . The attitude of LAURA and the coincidence of the despatch bring back to WILL the scene in Denver , and later in New York , and with that subtle intuition of the man of the world he connects the two .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: I do n't suppose , Laura , that you 'd be interested now in knowing anything about that young fellow out in Colorado ? What was his name — Madison ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Do you know anything ?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: No , nothing particularly . I 've been rather curious to know how he came out . He was a pretty fresh young man and did an awful lot of talking . I wonder how he 's doing and how he 's getting along . I do n't suppose by any chance you have ever heard from him ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Crosses to bureau .No , no ; I 've never heard .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: I presume he never replied to that letter you wrote ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: It would be rather queer , eh , if this young fellow shouldLooks at paper .happen to come across a lot of money — not that I think he ever could , but it would be funny , would n't it ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Yes , yes ; it would be unexpected . I hope he does . It might make him happy .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Think he might take a trip East and see you act . You know you 've got quite a part now .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Impatiently .I wish you would n't discuss this . Why do you mention it now ?Crossing to right of table .Is it because you were drinking last night and lost your sense of delicacy ? You once had some consideration for me . What I 've done I 've done . I 'm giving you all that I can . Please , please , do n't hurt me any more than you can help . That 's all I ask .

div.stage: Crossing up to mirror . Crosses back to right of table ; sits .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Well , I 'm sorry . I did n't mean that , Laura . I guess I am feeling a little bad to-day . Really , I do n't want to hurt your feelings , my dear . He gets up , goes to her , puts his hands on her shoulders , and his cheek close to the back of her head . She bends forward and shudders a little bit . It is very easy to see that the life she is leading is becoming intolerable to her .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: You know , dearie , I do a lot for you because you 've always been on the level with me . I 'm sorry I hurt you , but there was too much wine last night and I 'm all upset . Forgive me . LAURA , in order to avoid his caresses , has leaned forward ; her hands are clasped between her knees , and she is looking straight outward with a cold , impassive expression . WILL regards her silently for a moment . Really in the man 's heart there is an affection , and really he wants to try to comfort her ; but he seems to realize that she has slipped away from the old environment and conditions , and that he simply bought her back ; that he has n't any of her affection , even with his money ; that she evinces toward him none of the old camaraderie ; and it hurts him , as those things always hurt a selfish man , inclining him to be brutal and inconsiderate . WILL crosses to centre , and stands reading paper ; bell rings ; a pause and second bell . WILL seizes upon this excuse to go up-stage and over towards the door .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: After second bell .Damn that bell . He continues on his way ; he opens the door , leaves it open , and passes on to the outer door , which he opens . LAURA remains immovable and impassive , with the same cold , hard expression on her face . He comes in , slamming the outer door with effect , which one must have at this point of the play , because it is essential to a situation coming later . Enters the room , closes the door , and holds in his hand a telegram . Looks from newspaper to telegram .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: A wire .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: For me ?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: From whom , I wonder . Perhaps Elfie with a luncheon engagement .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Handing telegram to her .I do n't know . Here . Pause ; he faces her , looking at her . She opens it quickly . She reads it and , as she does , gasps quickly with an exclamation of fear and surprise . This is what the despatch saysit is dated at Buffalo and addressed to LAURA“ I will be in New York before noon . I 'm coming to marry you and I 'm coming with a bank-roll . I wanted to keep it secret and have a big surprise for you , but I can n't hold it any longer , because I feel just like a kid with a new top . Do n't go out , and be ready for the big matrimonial thing . All my love . John . ”

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: No bad news , I hope ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Walking up stage rather hurriedly .No , no — not bad news .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: I thought you were startled .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: No , not at all .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Looking at paper about where he had left off .Crosses to , and sits in armchair .From Elfie ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: No , just a friend .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Oh ! He makes himself rather comfortable in the chair , and LAURA regards him for a moment from up stage as if trying to figure out how to get rid of him .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Wo n't you be rather late getting down town , Will ?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Does n't make any difference . I do n't feel much like the office now . Thought I might order the car and take a spin through the park . The cold air will do me a lot of good . Like to go ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Crosses to sofa , and stands .No , not to-day . I thought your business was important ; you said so last night .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: No hurry . Do you — er — want to get rid of me ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Why should I ?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Expecting someone ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Crosses up to window .No — not exactly .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Lets curtain fly up .If you do n't mind , I 'll stay here .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Just as you please .A pause . Crosses to piano ; plays .Will ?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: How long does it take to come from Buffalo ?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Depends on the train you take .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: About how long ?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Between eight and ten hours , I think . Some one coming ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Do you know anything about the trains ?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Not much . Why do n't you find out for yourself ? Have Annie get the time-table ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: I will . Annie ! Annie !

div.stage: Rises from piano . ANNIE appears at doorway .

sp.speaker: ANNIE
sp.p: Yassum !

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Go ask one of the hall-boys to bring me a New York Central time-table .

sp.speaker: ANNIE
sp.p: Yassum ! Crosses the stage and exits through door . LAURA sits on left arm of sofa .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Then you do expect someone , eh ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Only one of the girls who used to be in the same company with me . But I 'm not sure that she 's coming here .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Then the wire was from her ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Did she say what train she was coming on ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Well , there are a lot of trains . About what time did you expect her in ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: She did n't say .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Do I know her ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: I think not . I met her while I worked in ‘ Frisco .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Resumes his paper .Oh ! ANNIE reënters with a time-table and hands it to LAURA .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Thanks ; take those breakfast things away , Annie .Sits on sofa .ANNIE complies ; takes them across stage , opens the door leading to the corridor , exits . LAURA in the meantime is studying the time-table .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: I can n't make this out .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Give it here ; maybe I can help you . LAURA crosses to right of table , sits opposite WILL , and hands him the time-table . He takes it and handles it as if he were familiar with it .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Where is she coming from ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: The West ; the telegram was from Buffalo . I suppose she was on her way when she sent it .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: There 's a train comes in here at 9 : 30 — that 's the Twentieth Century ,— that does n't carry passengers from Buffalo ; then there 's one at 11 : 41 ; one at 1 : 49 ; another at 3 : 45 ; another at 5 : 40 ; and another at 5 : 48 — that 's the Lake Shore Limited , a fast train ; and all pass through Buffalo . Did you think of meeting her ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: No . She 'll come here when she arrives .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Knows where you live ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: She has the address .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Ever been to New York before ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: I think not .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Passing her the time-table .Well , that 's the best I can do for you .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Crosses and puts time-table in desk .Thank you .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Takes up the paper again . LAURA looks at clock .By George , this is funny .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: What ?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Speak of the devil , you know .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Who ?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Your old friend Madison .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Utters a slight exclamation and makes an effort to control herself .What — what about him ?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: He 's been in Chicago .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: How do you know ?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Here 's a despatch about him .

lg.stage: Coming quickly over to him , looks over his shoulder .
lg.l: What — where — what 's it about ?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Well , I 'm damned if he has n't done what he said he 'd do — see !Holds the paper so that she can see . LAURA takes paper .He 's been in Chicago , and is on his way to New York . He 's struck it rich in Nevada and is coming with a lot of money . Queer , is n't it ?LAURA puts paper on table .Lights cigarette .Did you know anything about it ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Crosses to bureau .No , no ; nothing at all .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Lucky for him , eh ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Yes , yes ; it 's very nice .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Too bad he could n't get this a little sooner , eh , Laura ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Oh , I do n't know — I do n't think it 's too bad . What makes you ask ?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Oh , nothing . I suppose he ought to be here to-day . Are you going to see him if he looks you up ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Crosses to sofa and sits .No , no ; I do n't want to see him . You know that , do n't you , that I do n't want to see him ? What makes you ask these questions ?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Just thought you might meet him , that 's all . Do n't get sore about it .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: I 'm not . She holds the telegram crumpled in one hand . WILL lays down the paper , and regards LAURA curiously . She sees the expression on his face and averts her head in order not to meet his eye .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: What are you looking at me that way for ?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: I was n't conscious that I was looking at you in any particular way — why ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Oh , nothing . I guess I 'm nervous , too .

div.stage: Lies on sofa .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: A pause .I dare say you are .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: WILL crosses to LAURA .Yes , I am .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: You know I do n't want to delve into a lot of past history at this time , but I 've got to talk to you for a moment .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Rises and crosses a little to left .Why do n't you do it some other time ? I do n't want to be talked to now .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: But I 've got to do it just the same .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Trying to affect an attitude of resigned patience and resignation .Resuming seat on sofa .Well , what is it ?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: You 've always been on the square with me , Laura . That 's why I 've liked you a lot better than the other women .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Are you going into all that again now , this morning ? I thought we understood each other .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: So did I , but somehow I think that maybe we do n't quite understand each other .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Turns to WILL .In what way ?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Looking her straight in the eye .That letter I dictated to you the day that you came back to me , and left it for you to mail — did you mail it ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: You 're quite sure ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Yes , I 'm quite sure . I would n't say so if I was n't .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: And you did n't know Madison was coming East until you read about it in that newspaper ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: No — no , I did n't know .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Have you heard from him ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Crossing to extreme right .No — no — I have n't heard from him . Do n't talk to me about this thing . Why can n't you leave me alone ? I 'm miserable enough as it is .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Crossing to table .But I 've got to talk to you . Laura , you 're lying to me .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: She makes a valiant effort to become angry .What !

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: You 're lying to me , and you 've been lying to me , and I 've trusted you . Show me that telegram !

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Going over towards her .Show me that telegram !

div.stage: LAURA crosses up to doors leading into bedroom .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Tears telegram in half .You 've no right to ask me .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Are you going to make me take it awayLAURA crosses to window .from you ? I 'veCrosses to sofa .never laid my hands on you yet .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: It 's my business .

div.stage: Crossing to left of sofa , around it on down-stage side .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Yes , and it 's mine .

div.stage: During scene . Backing away from WILL , who is following her , LAURA backs against bureau . WILL grabs her and attempts to take telegram from her . She has put it in the front of her waist . She slowly draws it out .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: That telegram 's from Madison . Give it here !

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: No .

lg.l: I 'm going to find out where I stand . Give me that telegram , or
I 'll take it away from you .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Come on !

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: I 'll give it to you .Takes telegram out of waist , and hands it to him .He takes it slowly , looking her squarely in the eye . WILL crosses to centre , and does not glance away while he slowly smoothes it out so that it can be read ; when he finally takes it in both hands to read it she staggers back a step or two weakly .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Reads the telegram aloud .“ I will be in New York before noon . I 'm coming to marry you , and I 'm coming with a bank-roll . I wanted to keep it a secret and have a big surprise for you , but I can n't hold it any longer , because I feel just like a kid with a new top . Do n't go out , and be ready for the big matrimonial thing . All my love . John . ” Then you knew ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: But you did n't know he was coming until this arrived ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: And you did n't mail the letterTossing telegram on table, did you ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: What did you do with it ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: I — I burned it .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Why ?

div.stage: LAURA is completely overcome and unable to answer .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Why ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: I — I could n't help it — I simply could n't help it .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: So you 've been corresponding all this time .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: And he does n't knowWith a gesture around the room , indicating the condition in which they live .about us ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Taking a step towards her .By God , I never beat a woman in my life , but I feel as though I could wring your neck .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Why do n't you ? You 've done everything else . Why do n't you ?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Do n't you know that I gave Madison my word that if you came back to me I 'd let him know ? Do n't you know that I like that young fellow , and I wanted to protect him , and did everything I could to help him ? And do you know what you 've done to me ? You 've made me out a liar — you 've made me lie to a man — a man — you understand . What are you going to do now ? Tell me — what are you going to do now ? Do n't stand there as if you 've lost your voice — how are you going to square me ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: I 'm not thinking about squaring you . What am I going to do for him ?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Not what you are going to do for him — what am I going to do for him . Why , I could n't have that young fellow think that I tricked him into this thing for you or all the rest of the women of your kind on earth . God ! I might have known that you , and the others like you , could n't be square .The girl looks at him dumbly . He glances at his watch , walks up stage , looks out of the window , comes down again , goes to the table , and looks at her across it .You 've made a nice mess of it , have n't you ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Weakly .There is n't any mess . Please go away . He 'll be here soon . Please let me see him — please do that .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: No , I 'll wait . This time I 'm going to tell him myself , and I do n't care how tough it is .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Immediately regaining all her vitality .No , you must n't do that .Crossing back of table to centre .Oh , Will , I 'm not offering any excuse . I 'm not saying anything , but I 'm telling you the truth . I could n't give him up — I could n't do it . I love him .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Grins ; crosses to front of sofa .Huh .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Do n't you think so ? I know you can n't see what I see , but I do . And why can n't you go away ? Why can n't you leave me this ? It 's all I ever had . He does n't know . No one will ever tell him . I 'll take him away . It 's the best for him — it 's the best for me . Please go .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Why — do you think that I 'm going to let you trip him the way you tripped me ?Crosses and sits in armchair .No . I 'm going to stay right here until that young man arrives , and I 'm going to tell him that it was n't my fault . You were to blame .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Then you are going to let him know . You 're not going to give me a single , solitary chance ?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: I 'll give you every chance that you deserve when he knows . Then he can do as he pleases , but there must be no more deception , that 's flat .

div.stage: LAURA crosses and kneels beside WILL 'S chair .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Then you must let me tell him —WILL turns away impatiently .— yes , you must . If I did n't tell him before , I 'll do it now . You must go . If you ever had any regard for me — if you ever had any affection — if you ever had any friendship , please let me do this now . I want you to go — you can come back . Then you 'll see — you 'll know — only I want to try to make him understand that — that maybe if I am weak I 'm not vicious . I want to let him know that I did n't want to do it , but I could n't help it . Just give me the chance to be as good as I can be .WILL gives her a look .Oh , I promise you , I will tell him , and then — then I do n't care what happens — only he must learn everything from me — please — please — let me do this — it 's the last favour I shall ever — ever ask of you . Wo n't you ?

div.stage: LAURA breaks down and weeps .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Rising , looks at her a moment as if mentally debating the best thing to do . Crosses in front of table ; stands facing her with back to audience .All right , I wo n't be unkind . I 'll be back early this afternoon , and just remember , this is the time you 'll have to go right through to the end . Understand ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Yes , I 'll do it ,— all of it . Wo n't you please go — now ?

div.stage: Crosses ; sits in armchair .

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: All right .He exits into the bedroom and immediately enters again with overcoat on his arm and hat in hand ; he goes centre , and turns .I am sorry for you , Laura , but remember you 've got to tell the truth .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Who is sitting in a chair looking straight in front of her with a set expression .WILL exits .Please go . LAURA sits in a chair in a state of almost stupefaction , holding this attitude as long as possible . ANNIE enters , and in a characteristic manner begins her task of tidying up the room ; LAURA , without changing her attitude , and staring straight in front of her , her elbows between her knees and her chin on her hands .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Annie !

sp.speaker: ANNIE
sp.p: Yassum .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Do you remember in the boarding-house — when we finally packed up — what you did with everything ?

sp.speaker: ANNIE
sp.p: Yassum .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: You remember that I used to keep a pistol ?

sp.speaker: ANNIE
sp.p: Yo ’ all mean dat one yo ’ say dat gemman out West gave yuh once ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: ANNIE
sp.p: Yassum , Ah ‘ membuh it .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Where is it now ?

sp.speaker: ANNIE
sp.p: Crosses to writing-desk .Last Ah saw of it was in dis heah draw ’ in de writin ’ - desk .This speech takes her across to desk ; she opens the drawer , fumbles among a lot of old papers , letters , & c ., and finally produces a small thirty-two calibre , and gingerly crosses to LAURA .Is dis it ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Slowly turns around and looks at it .Yes . Put it back . I thought perhaps it was lost .ANNIE complies , when the bell rings . LAURA starts suddenly , involuntarily gathering her negligée gown closer to her figure , and at once she is under a great stress of emotion , and sways upon her feet to such an extent that she is obliged to put one hand out on to the table to maintain her balance . When she speaks , it is with a certain difficulty of articulation .See — who — that is — and let me know .

sp.speaker: ANNIE
sp.p: Turning .Crosses , opens the first door , and afterwards opens the second door .Yassum .

sp.speaker: ELFIE 'S VOICE
sp.p: Off stage .Hello , Annie ,— folks home ?

sp.speaker: ANNIE
sp.p: Yassum , she 's in . LAURA immediately evinces her tremendous relief , and ELFIE , without waiting for a reply , has shoved ANNIE aside and enters , ANNIE following and closing the door . ELFIE is beautifully gowned in a morning dress with an overabundance of fur trimmings and all the furbelows that would accompany the extravagant raiment generally affected by a woman of that type . ELFIE approaching effusively .

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: Hello , dearie .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Hello , Elfie . LAURA crosses and sits on sofa . ELFIE puts muff , & c ., on table .

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: It 's a bully day out .Crossing to bureau , looking in mirror .I 've been shopping all morning long ; just blew myself until I 'm broke , that 's all . My goodness , do n't you ever get dressed ? Listen .Crosses left of table to centre .Talk about cinches . I copped out a gown , all ready made , and fits me like the paper on the wall , for $ 37. 80 . Looks like it might have cost $ 200 . Anyway I had them charge $ 200 on the bill , and I kept the change . There are two or three more down town there , and I want you to go down and look them over . Models , you know , being sold out . I do n't blame you for not getting up earlier .She sits at the table , not noticing LAURA .That was some party last night . I know you did n't drink a great deal , but gee ! what an awful tide Will had on . How do you feel ?Looks at her critically .What 's the matter , are you sick ? You look all in . What you want to do is this — put on your duds and go out for an hour . It 's a perfectly grand day out . My Gaud ! how the sun does shine ! Clear and cold .A pause .Well , much obliged for the conversation . Do n't I get a “ Good-morning , ” or a “ How-dy-do , ” or a something of that sort ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: I 'm tired , Elfie , and blue — terribly blue .

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: Rises ; crosses to LAURA .Well now , you just brace up and cut out all that emotional stuff . I came down to take you for a drive . You 'd like it ; just through the park . Will you go ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Going up stage .Not this morning , dear ; I 'm expecting somebody .

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: A man ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Finding it almost impossible to suppress a smile .No , a gentleman .

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: Same thing . Do I know him ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: At desk , looking at clock .You 've heard of him .

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: Well , do n't be so mysterious . Who is he ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: What is your time , Elfie ?

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: Looks at her watch .Five minutes past eleven .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Oh , I 'm slow . I did n't know it was so late . Just excuse me , wo n't you , while I get some clothes on . He may be here any moment . Annie !

div.stage: She goes up stage towards portières .

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: Who ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: I 'll tell you when I get dressed . Make yourself at home , wo n't you , dear ?

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: I 'd sooner hear . What is the scandal anyway ?

lg.l: I 'll tell you in a moment . Just as soon as
Annie gets through with me .

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: Gets candy-box off desk , crosses , sits on arm of sofa , selecting candy . In a louder voice .Do you know , Laura , I think I 'll go back on the stage .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Off stage .Yes ?

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: Yes , I 'm afraid I 'll have to . I think I need a sort of a boost to my popularity .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: How a boost , Elfie ?

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: I think Jerry is getting cold feet . He 's seeing a little too much of mePlaces candy-box on sofa .nowadays .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: What makes you think that ?

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: I think he is getting a relapse of that front-row habit . There 's no use in talking , Laura , it 's a great thing for a girl 's credit when a man like Jerry can take two or three friends to the theatre , and when you make your entrance delicately point to you with his forefinger and say , “ The third one from the front on the left belongs to muh . ” The old fool 's hanging around some of these musical comedies lately , and I 'm getting a little nervous every time rent day comes .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Oh , I guess you 'll get along all right , Elfie .

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: With serene self-satisfaction .Oh , that 's a cinchRises ; crosses to table , looking in dresser mirror at herself , and giving her hat and hair little touches ., but I like to leave well enough alone , and if I had to make a change right now it would require a whole lot of thought and attention , to say nothing of the inconvenience , and I 'm so nicely settled in my flat .She sees the pianola .Say , dearie , when did you get the piano-player ? I got one of them phonographsCrosses to pianola , tries the levers , & c ., but this has got that beat a city block . How does it work ? What did it cost ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: I do n't know .

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: Well , Jerry 's got to stake me to one of these .Looks over the rolls on top . Mumbles to herself .“ Tannhauser , William Tell , Chopin . ”Then louder .Listen , dear . Ai n't you got anything else except all this high-brow stuff ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: What do you want ?

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: Oh , something with a regular tune to itLooks at empty box on pianola .Oh , here 's one ; just watch me tear this off .The roll is the tune of “ Bon-Bon Buddie , My Chocolate Drop . ” She starts to play and moves the lever marked “ Swell ” wide open , increases the tempo , and is pumping with all the delight and enthusiasm of a child .Ai n't it grand ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Gracious , Elfie , do n't play so loud . What 's the matter ?

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: I shoved over that thing marked “ Swell . ”Stops and turns . Rises ; crosses to centre and stands .I sure will have to speak to Jerry about this . I 'm stuck on that swell thing . Hurry up .LAURA appears .Gee ! you look pale .And then in a tone of sympathy :I 'll just bet you and Will have had a fight , and he always gets the best of you , does n't he , dearie ?LAURA crosses to dresser , and busies herself .Sits in armchair .Listen . Do n't you think you can ever get him trained ? I almost threw Jerry down the stairs the other night and he came right back with a lot of American beauties and a check . I told him if he did n't look out I 'd throw him down-stairs every night . He 's getting too damned independent and it 's got me nervous . Oh , dear , I s'pose I will have to go back on the stage .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: In the chorus ?

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: Well , I should say not . I 'm going to give up my musical career . Charlie Burgess is putting on a new play , and he says he has a part in it for me if I want to go back . It is n't much , but very important ,— sort of a pantomime part . A lot of people talk about me , and just at the right time I walk across the stage and make an awful hit . I told Jerry that if I wentLAURA crosses to sofa , picks up candy-box , puts it upon desk , gets telegram from table , crosses to centre .on he 'd have to come across with one of those Irish crochet lace gowns . He fell for it . Do you know , dearie , I think he 'd sell out his business just to have me back on the stage for a couple of weeks , just to give box-parties every night for my en-trance and ex-its .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Seriously .LAURA takes ELFIE by the hand , and leads her over to sofa . LAURA sits , ELFIE standing .Elfie !

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: Yes , dear .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Come over here and sit down .

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: What 's up ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Do you know what I 'm going to ask of you ?

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: Sits opposite LAURA .If it 's a touch , you 'll have to wait until next week .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: No : just a little advice .

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: With a smile .Well , that 's cheap , and Lord knows you need it . What 's happened ? LAURA takes the crumpled and torn telegram that WILL has left on the table and hands it to ELFIE . The latter puts the two pieces together , reads it very carefully , looks up at LAURA about middle of telegram , and lays it down .

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: Well ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Will suspected . There was something in the paper about Mr. Madison — the telegram came — then we had a row .

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: Serious ?

lg.l: Yes . Do you remember what I told you about that letter — the one
Will made me write — I mean to John — telling him what I had done ?

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: Yes , you burned it .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: I tried to lie to Will — he would n't have it that way . He seemed to know . He was furious .

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: Did he hit you ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: No ; he made me admit that John did n't know , and then he said he 'd stay here and tell himself that I 'd made him lie , and then he said something about liking the other man and wanting to save him .

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: Save — shucks ! He 's jealous .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: I told him if he 'd only go I 'd — tell John myself when he came , and now you see I 'm waiting — and I 've got to tell — and — and I do n't know how to begin — and — and I thought you could help me — you seem so sort of resourceful , and it means — it means so much to me . If John turned on me now I could n't go back to Will , and , Elfie ,— I do n't think I 'd care to — stay here any more .

sp.speaker: ELFIE
sp.p: What !In an awestruck tone , taking LAURA in her arms impulsively .Dearie , get that nonsense out of your head and be sensible . I 'd just like to see any two men who could make me think about — well — what you seem to have in your mind .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: But I do n't know ; do n't you see , Elfie , I do n't know . If I do n't tell him , Will will come back and he 'll tell him , and I know John and maybe — Elfie , do you know , I think John would kill him .

sp.speaker: ELFIE
